content: The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act Amendments of 1998, also known as the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act, aims to encourage private gifts for the conservation of fish, wildlife, and plant resources under the Department of the Interior and the Department of Commerce. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act Amendments of 1998 establishes a governing Board of Directors consisting of 25 members representing diverse viewpoints on conservation. Directors are not federal employees. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act Amendments of 1998 establishes a governing Board of Directors consisting of 25 members representing diverse viewpoints on conservation. Directors are not federal employees. The Foundation appoints the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service and the Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere as Directors. The Secretary of the Interior appoints 23 members after consulting with the Secretary of Commerce and considering recommendations from the Board. The Secretary of the Interior appoints 23 Directors for the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, with specific criteria for their expertise in conservation. Directors serving on the Board at the time of enactment will continue their terms. The Secretary of the Interior appoints 8 new Directors to the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation within 45 days of enactment. Each Director (excluding certain members) serves a 6-year term, with initial appointments made by the Secretary. The Secretary appoints 8 Directors to the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation for terms of 2, 4, and 6 years. Vacancies must be filled within 45 days, and appointees serve the remainder of the term for unexpired positions. An individual can serve a maximum of 2 consecutive terms as a Director of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Foundation. Technical amendments are made to clarify references to the Board and Foundation in relevant sections of the Establishment Act. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to include the Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of Commerce in relevant sections. SEC. 4. RIGHTS AND OBLIGATIONS OF THE FOUNDATION. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to allow the Foundation to have its principal office in a county in Maryland or Virginia bordering the District of Columbia. It also grants the Foundation the authority to invest federal funds in US obligations and securities guaranteed by the United States, as well as to deposit funds provided by the Federal Government. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to allow the Foundation to invest federal funds in US obligations and securities guaranteed by the United States, as well as to deposit funds provided by the Federal Government into insured accounts. Additionally, the Foundation can use interest or investment income for its purposes and make payments under cooperative agreements with private landowners for the restoration of wildlife resources on private land. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to require the Foundation to notify the Federal agency administering the program before acquiring or receiving funds, with a 45-day objection period. Section 304 of Public Law 102-440 is repealed, and the Foundation must notify the agency before conveying or providing federal funds. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to require the Foundation to convey real property acquired with Federal funds at fair market value after notifying the Federal agency, with a 45-day objection period. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to allow the Foundation to convey property if it is no longer valuable for conservation purposes and better serves the Foundation's authorized activities. Section 4 of the Act is also amended to remove a limitation on condemnation and to restrict expenditures of Federal funds on printing services or capital equipment. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to restrict expenditures of Federal funds on printing services or capital equipment exceeding $10,000 without approval from the administering Federal agency. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 10 of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to authorize appropriations of $25,000,000 to the Department of the Interior and $5,000,000 to the Department of Commerce for fiscal years 1999 through 2003. The funds must be provided to the Foundation in advance on October 1 or soon after, and are to be used as specified. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act authorizes funds to be provided to the Foundation for matching contributions from private persons and government agencies. Federal funds cannot be used for administrative expenses. Additionally, the Foundation may accept additional Federal funds for conservation efforts. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act allows the Foundation to use federal funds for conservation efforts and matching contributions from private persons and government agencies. Grant amounts cannot be used for litigation expenses or lobbying activities to influence legislation. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON AUTHORITY. The National Fish and Wildlife Foundation Establishment Act is amended to state that the Foundation cannot perform functions authorized for the National Park Foundation by Public Law 90-209.
